text:
@Wyldina My dad is helping as much as he can, but honestly he’s as much as a mess as we are.

I’m just grateful my siblings and I are so close and all working together seamlessly, which I know isn’t true for every family.

The cruelest part of my mom dying is all the funeral planning there is to do when I’m feeling least able to do it.

Very thankful for my partner and my close friends who are helping so much.

My mom passed away suddenly on Monday. We still don’t know why, but have been told it ways likely quick and without pain.

It doesn’t feel real. I spoke to her on Sun and she seemed 100% fine.

If you see this, please let it act as a reminder to hug and/or talk to your loved ones
@Mollys_ADHD It me
@WhatTheADHD I don’t personally care or even notice, but yes, this is something some people definitely care about.

@annagranta It went like this: 

My brother was diagnosed with ADHD and explained all the actual symptoms of ADHD to me (not just the stereotypical ones) and I realised I also matched the symptoms 100%. It wasn’t just one thing.

#askADHD How do you deal with that thing where you shutdown when there is too much to do and it's all a bit overwhelming? 

Looking for good advice and tips!
@wynneliz1 Yes!!!!! I have alarms for the end of the day too, otherwise I would just not notice, not eat dinner, not stop.

@danidonovan Non-shoutout to the teachers who noticed ADHD students falling asleep in class because they wouldn't let them fidget or doodle, and then made them sit at the front and punished them for still falling asleep in class 2 feet away from them.
@jessejanderson @danidonovan This is me tbh
@youneedcoolin Take care of yourself first.
@AdhdEditor That would definitely be easier than the approach I'm taking, which is loads of therapy and experimentation.
@thomasvye Yeah, probably most of this is actually I'm too tired to keep it up anymore, to be fair.
@i_am_remy_bot haha i didn't think of that
@SonAndHeirOf I think it will take time to untangle and figure it out, but it definitely seems worth it<3
@ruthbath @AuntimusPrime wut
@Frag1771 Seems like they do, mate. Have a nice life.
@maxwbartley Ha yeah I'm still figuring out exactly HOW to do it, to be honest.
@arisendead I know it will take a long time to untangle 30 years of masking, but it seems worth it.
@Lostbrain15 That's a really good point<3

@Kathari59945251 That's what I've realised over the years. People I know now and work with now accept me as I am, and even appreciate my unique quirks, and when I'm masking, people can tell it's not genuine.
@_sallyjo I guess I think I can bear it at this point in my life.
@smolkiwian It has taken me a long time, and I'm sure it will take even longer to learn how to actually do it! Good luck!

I'm done masking. I'm so over trying to be a sanitized version of myself, coming off snobby even though it's just fear of being judged and outcast.

I'm too loud, overly enthusiastic, extremely emotional, weirdly blunt, and kind of a ADHD mess, but that's me.
@lilrascalishere Hate them. Need them.
@blueskye12367 I don't like caffeine and I do like alcohol, maybe a bit too much.
@SilverMoon_lake @COLETTESEZO Oh haha, I assumed you meant from like 10 years ago or something.
@shanedkeene Cheers to that

@AimiHamraie That seems to be always how it goes for me. Spend a lot of mental energy worrying about those lingering tasks for ages, and then one day just sit down and be able to blast through a bunch of them.
Another day another delay (to the items I've been putting off on my to-do list for months).
@AdvantageAdhd If they're type A they'll probably love that haha

@yourpalomar Haha, I mean I am terrible at completing side projects for non-ADHD related reasons, but for design work, I follow a pretty rigid process of research, discovery, sketching, iteration, testing, and then final design, setting time limits for each stage (especially ideation).

@adhdudette @TomJSeiple Have heard this so many times from folks! Manage to hold down a good job, manage to have gotten through school okay, and so struggles are dismissed, even though that person's life could be made 100x easier and more enjoyable with proper treatment.
@DopamineShark Genuinely useful. I think there is also probably a cultural context to how we understand these words.

@mangohatface good thing adhd piles don't count!

tidied!
@FiTiddleDeDe @focuswithfaigy that is also very true to be fair
@purplegnomling @dmntd1974 TRUE
@isntJen Oh my goooood 😂

@focuswithfaigy Mostly bad design I think. Low legibility + readability, so hard for anyone to read, but also low visual hierarchy (ie. no variation between importance of different types of information), which is definitely even more problematic for ADHDers than for most.

Excel sux basically.
@streetlightdawn it is truly a blessing from a higher power
@hels oooh hell no

@TheNapMinistry I was tired for a while, but at a certain point I think some kind of sanity switch flipped in my brain and I stopped fighting it and now I just want to be fully uploaded online as soon as possible, abandon my body like the husk of a shedded snake skin, and embrace the metaverse.

@RoseyRebecca spend your life researching how to make yourself immortal and then do it.

oh except that last part might be hard if you have adhd
@StephGrajek_ATC glad it worked out<3
@ADHDJobs @birdbrainmd3 one day... 😍
@Jodieinfinity ffs, sorry you're going through this. so frustrating.
@streetlightdawn this made me laugh so hard legit, incredible
@thomasdj Thank you for validating me, I needed that
@Jodieinfinity wtfffff, honestly, what is with doctors sometimes treating you like an idiot who knows nothing, and then other times treating you like you should be a medical expert???
@ADHDJobs @birdbrainmd3 Thank you!!! I love sausage dogs too! Grew up with corgis, so it's always been a dream of mine to have another one:)

Anyone else ever been super proud of themselves for scrimpin' and savin' enough that you could finally maybe think about buying an actual house...

...and then you meet estate agents and they make the budget you thought was pretty damn good feel so, so small like you still broke?
@ADHDJobs @birdbrainmd3 Working on finding and buying first house first, then will work on the corgi!
@MumOfASpoonie Absolute shambles:(

@JoannaNoBanana Never understood the reasoning behind telling someone this as a response to them sharing their struggles.

Like, in what world could it possibly be helpful or comforting instead of making the person feel worse???
@birdbrainmd3 @ADHDJobs Bookmarking this in my brain for when I finally get my corgi.
@alysurr @peacelovewords @HermeticOpus 100%

@sekeidesign I hate the feeling when the trackpad of a MacBook doesn't do the tactile clicky thing when you're expecting it to do it.

It's like touching something dead.
@adhdadulting rude tbh
@0bliqueStrategy Did you end up getting proper treatment? I'm desperate to talk to someone who has actually been through it at Maudsley!
@seeing4d @HomeEdHub I dunno, but if this diagnosis process continues to be this painful, I'll definitely be making a complaint.
@ADHD_Hustler It definitely helps.
@seeing4d @HomeEdHub I feel almost entirely certain that they've had people meltdown during these calls before. I was baaarely holding it together by the end.
@davejmurphy Lol yeah, nothing I can do about that unfortunately. I only use royalty-free music on stream, but Twitch seems to do this ever so often for whatever reason despite that.
@seeing4d @HomeEdHub Agreed. They're absolutely using a flawed, potentially damaging diagnostic process, no matter what the purpose of it is.

@davejmurphy @MyPocketSand @smolkiwian I have no idea, my friend. None at all.

Bureaucracy is not something ADHD folks are very good at figuring out haha

@katalat @VictoriaHampst1 It really depends on the person. I know ADHD adults who have had lots of success with medication, and some that choose not to take it for whatever reason. 

ADHD medication does work for most adults though, there is lots of scientific evidence showing that.

@ADHD_Hustler Thank you so much haha<3

It's just hard to remind myself in the moment of that sometimes!
@TomJSeiple @adhdudette Absolutely.

@Writer99Ghost They didn't even ask me questions about the answers, they just asked me the same questions again that they presumably had my answers to right in front of them, and then asked for examples.

Like, I could have written examples on the form if that's what they wanted.

@angry_pingu_blm @HermeticOpus The thing is, I actually already have a private diagnosis, just my NHS GP suddenly decided not to support the private care. 

It's all a fucking mess, tbh.
@rushiv @ADHD_Hustler I feel like it's usually harder to get away with incompetency in smaller companies than in bigger ones. Give yourself some credit <3
@MissKAllen89 Absolutely ridiculous. Cheaper to get arrested tbh
@ahi_hay_alguien Yeah I'm aware of that. If it was up to me, I'd ban private healthcare altogether.

@anneireann @artpoetryfan Yeah I have no idea why they need to do a separate diagnosis, to be honest, but I've been told that's just how it works.

So inefficient, and so frustrating.
@keikiorchid Eurgh, sorry to hear.

@artpoetryfan And yes, I agree, this is because the private sector isn't regulated. 

The poor level of care at the high price felt like a fucking scam, to be honest. I feel safer in the care of the NHS, where there checks and balances on doctors.

@artpoetryfan They did not do titration, recommended meds that don't have much research behind them at all before trying standard ADHD meds, and provided no follow up support, just give you a scrip say bye.

Also the doc said her patients were 100% satisfied, and I was like, you didn't ask me.

Had a good moan about this on stream today, tbh. If you want to join a bunch of mentally ill and neurodiverse people moaning about the absolute state of healthcare systems around the world, give me a follow here:

https://t.co/wX1rK4pEUT

@katalat @VictoriaHampst1 Medication is one of the most effective treatments for ADHD symptoms, and getting a diagnosis is the only way to get it.

Diagnosis also can give access to workplace supports, although I'm self employed so idc about that.
@AdvantageAdhd Paperless as much as possible, and delegate the rest of it to my partner, tbh.

@HermeticOpus @LisaHannahThom YES!!! Had a massive discussion about this on my stream today.

Turns out, all the adult ADHDers agree, we wouldn't "leave our seats in situations in which sitting is expected" because ADHD doesn't equal socially inept!

Live streaming  now, chatting about my NHS ADHD diagnosis experience, and then getting into a co-working/body-doubling session:

https://t.co/wX1rK4pEUT
@AdhdAngsty Sending good vibes, hope it all goes okay.

@LauraFMcConnell Lol my mom is mostly deaf and literally she always does this when she's "done" with something. It's brilliant, and the exaggerated way she does it is so fucking funny to me, it's just like, *sigh*, nope. I cry laughing every time.

@adhdudette @TomJSeiple When I was diagnosed, the psychiatrist helpfully explained to me that ADHD treatment isn't about what you've been able to accomplish, it's about how much you've struggled to get there in spite of your challenges.

We shouldn't have to struggle so hard.

@daphnedescends_ @katharineparton I hope I end up getting to be diagnosed by a psych like you who understands! Have heard mixed reviews of NHS diagnosis, but at least with the public system you can request a different doctor, have routes to find what you need, vs with private healthcare where you don't.
@theviewfromNo20 @AryehKahn1 BAN PRIVATE HEALTHCARE IN THE UK
@chelsea_ferrin Lol oh yeah, I often forget that I hate being comfortable and bored even more than I hate paperwork.
@AmberPechin Does it ever end?

Bringing out the big guns for max ADHD focus today:
https://t.co/KTMupK1PZG

@adhdudette Me, just over here neurotically writing down everything ever because it means I only have a 30% chance of forgetting those things vs a 95% chance of forgetting them.

😭
@AryehKahn1 Yeah, what the UK is doing now is extremely backwards and harmful tbh
@daphnedescends_ @katharineparton I found all the questions quite vague to be honest, it did make me wonder if I had answered the "same" on the form versus on the call.
@phrebh_ @randomfrequency @AdultingADHD When have ADHDers ever been that concerned about what is healthy for us though? 😂
@crystalenka That is true, to be fair. Why do all the best, most freeing things require SO MUCH PAPERWORK???

@MyPocketSand @smolkiwian So frustrating that it's like this!!!

I have a diagnosis already too, but for whatever reason the NHS makes you get a new one with them to receive treatment from them.

Including:
- NHS ADHD diagnosis 
- private ADHD diagnosis
- U.K. visas
- U.K. citizenship
- U.K. passport
- EU citizenship
- EU passport
- starting a business
- business taxes and accounting
- renting a flat
- getting a mortgage
- buying a house (trying)

Lately been wondering why I’ve chosen seemingly the most anti-ADHD, paperwork-filled lifestyle ever. 

Like why do the things I want to do in life all seem to require endless paperwork, ie. The thing I hate most in life?
@katharineparton No idea. I’d love to ask someone who works there if this is why.

@ADHD_Hustler Literally everything I’ve ever done, but I guess it’s most obvious in my career. Quit my cushy agency job in Feb 2020 and somehow managed to grow my independent design practice to multiple six figures despite the shit timing.

But I still question whether I’m a good designer.

@pigletish Thinking that things will probably not be this bad forever.

So, hope I guess?
@AdhdAngsty Hard relate to that. Things will get better ❤️‍🩹
@HealthyADHD Treat yourself with kindness and love.
@SilverMoon_lake @COLETTESEZO It’s literally the exact same forms now except they’ve turned it into an interactive PDF (poorly built) that you can fill in on your computer.
@artpoetryfan I’ve already had a private diagnosis, but I found the level of care privately was terrible.
@TetanusAdmiral @AdultingADHD Yeah it is different depending on the region, but I remember I didn’t get a letter back about the referral for months, so long that I was surprised to even receive it.
@Dreadfulfurrows @mrsbettysbooks Good to hear!
@TrippySpaceBun Haha yes!!! Everyone I work with knows I need to write everything down to have even a hope of remembering it.

@HermeticOpus I think it’s fine to ask about childhood, as a hallmark of ADHD is that it begins in childhood, but yeah with masking and being incredibly shy and quiet, keen not to be noticed, some people don’t fit the stereotypical presentation they seem to be looking for.
@Millie_Woodcock Oh no, hope it goes okay
@DreTop1a Definitely a pet peeve for me!

@Clodagh_Lunaria I imagine your advice is probably a little bit more involved than just saying “Have you tried making a list?”

If the advice is just that, then no it’s not helpful, but I imagine as an ADHDer you probably have a lot of specific advice about how you’ve made lists work for you
@validish @ResilientPlus Definitely bringing that onboard as a good rule for life.

@randomfrequency @phrebh_ @AdultingADHD Yeah for sure. People I know back in Canada definitely had the easiest time compared to my experience here in the U.K. and what this person just described as their US experience, so I guess if we’re being competitive then fully socialised Canada wins.
@Zalacoza It was over the phone (no video) with a nurse who is writing up a report for the doctor to read.
@somewhereM40 Yeah it definitely seems based on the DIVA assessment which seems to be mainly for diagnosing hyperactive little kids.
@HemilyTiger Yea NHS is the public healthcare service in the UK
@Deerthingies Unfortunately for them they made me wait two years and so I am desperate for treatment.
@COLETTESEZO The PDFs did have multiple errors in how they had built the interactive forms, so yeah for sure that's part of it.
@jessejanderson Ha I feel you on that. It was definitely hard for me today to not get frustrated at the person on the phone, I'm not going to lie.
@COLETTESEZO Is it designed to make people give up, like the other mental health services I've received from the NHS?
@OneRedSock Sounds about right tbh. Esp. since I've already been diagnosed privately.

@RonarCorruption They had me do that already actually and requested it be a parent, so I rang up my mom, but she lives in another country and I'm a fully grown woman so I had to have my partner fill in the "last 6 months" part of the questionnaire, not my mum.

@HermeticOpus Like a lot. I kept reiterating how shy and withdrawn I was as a child. I'd never get up out of my seat for fear of getting in trouble. I'd never interrupt, for fear of getting in trouble.
@Ellslvs YES! It's literally my job as a designer to make things work better and more efficiently too, so it's super-super frustrating personally to have to deal with inefficient systems.
@adhdexerciser They said it's due to Covid still.

@jessejanderson Yeah it was difficult, to be honest, but with these kinds of things it's never the individual person's fault. The nurse I spoke to was fine really, and I'm sure it wasn't her idea that this is the way she has to do it.

@DesignyAlex Haha, that's a bit how I felt about mine.

The actual person doing it was fine, and I don't blame her or any individual for how awful the experience was tbh.
@3L_strugglebus Yeah, I can't imagine why they would think this is the best way to do it, but who knows.

I do co-working/body-doubling streams that I also like to think of as a safe space to talk ADHD issues and get peer support and advice (the kind that actually helps).

Follow me here to check them out:
https://t.co/wX1rK4pEUT
@Jasperlope From what I've heard of the US system they're both pretty bad, yeah.
@rolandhesz Same back at you!!!

@Hannah_cannot Horrible:(

Such a shambles, honestly, this system.
@Jasperlope Jesus, that's disgusting tbh.

@SquishIsShort That was the same for me! I had to reach out to them a few times to make sure I was on it, and last time I rang them they just told me that day was "my lucky day" and I'd reached the end of the waiting list.

Were they ever going to tell me that if I didn't ring them?

@jessejanderson Yeah, weirdly, it was actually pretty uncomfortable going through all the details of my upbringing and mental health history over the phone for 2 hours with someone I've never spoken to before.
OH YOU MEAN THE SAME THINGS I ALREADY WROTE UP FOR YOU ON THE FORMS?

Can I also moan about the fact that the next stage of this is apparently they will get back to me "in a few weeks" to schedule the next call?

When I questioned why it takes a few weeks, they said they had to "write this up", referring to the things we'd discussed on the call.
@3L_strugglebus The thing is, she did read it, she was referencing bits of it in front of her, but she was also just asking the exact things that were on the form.
@mmfhbf1 I'm right there with ya
@sallynilsson5 Definitely<3

@dmntd1974 omg, it's like, yeah that would be useful advice except for literally the main symptom of ADHD is that part of our brain don't work too well!!!! 

adlksjdflkjsadl

Had my "assessment call", the first part of NHS ADHD diagnosis today and...

It was literally just a 2 hr call where they asked me the same questions that were on the form they had me fill out.

Maybe I'm just in a mood, but is this one of the reasons the waiting list is 2 years?
@ResilientPlus Lemme know if you think of something good plz
@MsKackiV Yeah that sounds like waaaay too much!

@sumunthuh Exactly. Like, if I feel like educating, sure, I'll do it, but it's really not my job to be going around educating every single person who does this to me (it's a lot). 

I don't have the energy, and frankly, I doubt these specific people are the types who are open to be educated

@MikeBishopMusic Sorry, I'm in a really bad mood today tbh 😅

But also it's just hard to brush this feeling off when it happens all the time, and doesn't often the response to trying to educate is that the person doesn't care to be educated.

@sumunthuh THIS! Like, it almost has nothing to do with them "not understanding ADHD". I think if anyone goes around giving extremely basic advice on anything, it says a lot about what they think of other people, ADHD or not.
@FungusDan @AskADHD yes
@SaintsFan467 I'm normally okay with them, but today it's just like... way too much to be asked to deal with talking to someone unprompted, unscheduled.

I just really cannot be dealing with anyone calling me on the PHONE today on top of everything.

If the phone rings again I rlly might cry tbh.

Why is this the thing that sends me over the edge?
Yeah that was terrible 😅
@yellowharms @FromAerin I guess it's a good barometer for unearthing which folks are empathetic and which aren't.
@TomJSeiple Totally agree.

@AaronBeedlegame It's just that it literally happens all the time.

When it's a pattern, you start to internalise it.
@yellowharms @FromAerin Some folks can, but tbh the people who answer like this must lack some kind of basic capacity for empathy.
@ShojiQWQ lol yeah except my job is on my pc so eurghdskalfkjasdl/
@kcAndersome For sure! I have plenty of tips, tricks, strategies, etc. They all help, but sometimes nothing works and I still struggle.
@MikeBishopMusic Eh, it's not my job to educate people, and sometimes I don't feel like it.
@coachcamg You're not wrong.

@Quincy_Francis That's it, it makes you feel like the people saying those things to you are assuming you didn't even bother to try, when actually you're trying harder than anyone and still struggling. Horrible.
@doomscroll_bot lul no

ADHD is having an event today that you've been looking forward to for weeks, but unfortunately it seems like today is going to be one of those days you just can't activate your brain very well, so you're going to have to just muddle through it.
@bluerushy https://t.co/Svglomdj0G
@4omar9 The only appropriate way to respond, to be honest
@amy_b_inHD I love having him on in background while I work in the mornings!
@distortarte @DaftLimmy Totally agree

Sharing your ADHD struggles with someone, and then getting a response like, "Have you tried making a list" is more than just annoying.

Getting given basic/simple advice feels like they're assuming you're too stupid to have come up with the obvious answer on your own.

@Mrs_Z_Primary A friend of mine's work did this a few years ago, and while my friend was not overweight, he is very competitive and a bit mad, so he ended up starving himself for a month just to win the competition.

He got quite ill by the end of it, but he got a $100 gift card out of it.
@leo_guinan @Natalie_Furn @NotechAna @StroutMotivateU @tinanayak23 @tatfig @DorseyMc @GraceBanyan BLESS

@ceremonialhat Getting started is often the hardest part for me too. It's like, I forget that I actually always really enjoy doing my work, but actually getting the executive function to ramp up into starting is an absolute nightmare most days, ngl.
@4omar9 @DaftLimmy It’s a book https://t.co/BSQFI9m6Nl
@witheringenigma @DaftLimmy https://t.co/BSQFI9m6Nl
@Hannah_cannot Classes work well for me too, the accountability of it I guess.

Just read @DaftLimmy ’s autobiography, and spent the whole thing thinking it’s weirdly relatable to my own life experiences.

Then it literally ended with cliffhanger of him saying he’s booked an appointment to see a doctor about maybe having ADHD.

 And I was just like OOOoOOOh.
@TheADHDKirsty Dancing is totally exercise though! You’re doing it!
@Wyldina Haha omg this is exactly the kind of thing my friends and family make fun of me for 😂

@AyLilGiraffe Why is any boost of hormones going to have bigger impact for us? 

I guess it wasn’t that obvious to me…
@UOtterLiveOnce Oh yeah I burn out all the time 😂
@queerbunny_ @nickmward @svershbow Woosh

Before being diagnosed, I always wondered why it felt like I “needed” exercise more than other people, but if people with ADHD actually get MORE benefit from exercise than others, it kinda makes sense. https://t.co/pHUOPtxJYG
@themightyjungle @DrLaCount I literally love exercise. Saved my life.

@victoria_st16 @DrLaCount Don’t worry about consistency, especially to begin with. Guilt and shame from not being able to stick to a plan the way we’re told we “should” makes it so much harder.

Just to the smallest, tiniest steps you can until you build it up.

@DrLaCount Explains why I’ve always been such a freak about exercise, to the point where people I know ask, “Why do you do it so much?”

Like if there’s actually more benefit for me, it kinda makes sense why other people don’t seem to “get” why I’m so active.

@HowtoADHD Before I knew about ADHD and hyperfocus, I thought hyperfocus was how productive I should be all the time, and blamed myself for not being able to summon that level of productivity whenever I wanted.
@nickmward @svershbow My first boyfriend broke up with me via msn messenger so I get that
@ADHD_superhero 100% exactly my experience too
@svershbow How does this make us important?
@nickmward @svershbow 1989, I guess I’m a bit too young to have had man messenger

Me: I wish people would have more patience and understanding for me when I’m struggling with my ADHD symptoms.

Also me: Everything is so slow and boring, people need to get up to my speed.
@maqusan i didn't have the cultural context, i was so confused
@maqusan wut
@maqusan Wut

When you too tired and overwhelmed to take a nap but you need sleep.
@verenahallam YES! This is it! I feel like I need to do more of this, and maybe someday, somewhere I'll finally stop feeling like I don't work hard enough.

That ADHD rage when a work crew with a woodchipper decides to park right outside your office.

@514hooligan Bless

@egauderman @shiftlessssheep This is the kind of productivity tip that’s great for ADHD tbh.

Two weeks ago I started working on a project for a new client, and I’ve spent most of this time feeling like I hadn’t done nearly enough.

Today I had to write a summary of what I’ve been working on, and you know what, it’s actually objectively what I would call a helluvalot.
@RobBradford17 Has your therapist tried actually doing therapy?

Oh no, you guys, I've made a to-do list, but, whaddaya know, I still can't get started on my work! 

This is a real shock to me.

Wow, maybe a having a to-do list hasn't actually cured my ADHD???

Wow.

Stunned.

@HowtoADHD My neck muscles have actually seized up because I spent too much time working in bed without my meds.

It’s great.

@mik_draws But also, if you don't think your boss will be A-okay with ADHD, you can ask for accommodations without labelling yourself, and say that the current work setup isn't working for you, and maybe make some suggestions about how to change things so you can do your best work.

@mik_draws I was diagnosed after I became self-employed, but I'll say: be careful, there is a still a lot of stigma around ADHD in the workplace, so there is a chance your boss will be dismissive or start treating you differently.

This is a ramble, and I don't know if it makes sense, but learning how to spot and name your emotions before they become overwhelming is super useful, has made me less afraid of my own feelings, and in general made life 100x easier.

For some people with ADHD, we don't even notice what we're feeling until the feeling is so strong it overwhelms us. 

Like, how was I supposed to know I was feeling sad because of a particular cause if the feeling of sadness didn't become overwhelming until days later? Impossible

Sometimes I think about how little I used to understand or even notice my emotions compared to now (after years of therapy and self-work), and I'm just like... how did I manage to do anything?

I used to just feel like strong emotions came out of nowhere to ruin my day.
@maybeADHdee This was me yesterday at 4pm, I just could not work anymore. I think it was the booster shot, but I literally HAD to take a nap!

@maybeADHdee I'm exactly the same tbh. Been working on getting better at it, but it's hard to break the habit of feeling you can/should be able to do everything.

I know it's easy to get down on awareness when there are lots of other issues we have to overcome with access to treatment, etc, but so many people are just living like I was, feeling like something was wrong, but not knowing what. Awareness can save lives too.

I was diagnosed with ADHD at age 30.

I didn't know what ADHD even was until age 30, aside from the stereotypes.

As soon as I finally learned what ADHD actually is, I was able to learn about it and change my life for the better.

#ADHDAwarenessMonth 
#ADHDAcceptanceMonth

Another, less serious one, I had some bread, cheese and a bit of chorizo for breakfast just now, and the chorizo was really nice, and I just had the thought, ’what if I just ate the whole chorizo? That would be great!’

When like, obviously, eating a whole chorizo would be awful.

For example, I’m writing this on my iPad and I just saw the Apple pencil sitting on top of it and had the thought, ’oooh I could just draw all day, that would really boost my mood and make me feel creative’.

And then I had to remind myself I have client work to do.

A part of my ADHD medication I don’t love, is that along with allowing me to remember my motivations, there is also always an initial surge of excitement, where everything seems appealing for like half an hour.
@ADHDrizzle This tweet deserves more attention

And then the medication kicks in and I suddenly have the executive function to be able to stop, think for a second, and access my long term and short term goals, the things I am excited about working on currently, etc.

Just realized one of the reasons ADHD medication helps me get started on Monday mornings is because I struggle to remember what my motivations are for the tasks I planned to do.

It’s like, ‘why on earth would I want to do this work, when I could spend my time doing fun stuff?’
Sitting here on the sofa on a Monday morning waiting for ADHD medication to start working so I can stop feeling like today is a big “nope” and at least attempt to get something done.

I’d heard the advice to keep quick food and snacks on hand before, but without a reason why that I actually cared about, I never managed to do it.
Sometimes ADHD strategies are all about finding ways to reframe the way you think about things you’re struggling with, finding something that truly motivates you or interests you about the thing.

I think about this a lot, because it worked. Now instead of thinking I have to make a good, healthy, perfect meal for it to count, and not eating if I couldn’t, I make sure to always have quick, high protein things on hand, and at least get in at least a little bit of food.

I once asked my ADHD coach about how to deal with struggling to eat regular meals everyday, and she recommended reframing eating as a requirement, because we need to eat with our ADHD medicine for it to work properly, so to prioritise just eating something, anything at meal times

@AdhdElite @TheBitchyBee1 @WhatTheADHD @ADDeeCee @ABCsofADHD @ADHDelaide There's plenty of accounts that do this, including lots of big ones that make tons of money off reposted content, but just because lots of people do it doesn't make it a cool thing to do.

You got called out for it, now it's your choice whether you want to keep doing it or not.

@AdhdElite @TheBitchyBee1 @WhatTheADHD @ADDeeCee @ABCsofADHD @ADHDelaide Not illegal, just morally dubious and not considered good internet etiquette. 

Twitter famously has a retweet function, so copy/pasting the text from someone else's tweet into the "compose tweet" box and then tweeting it out implies that you came up with the content.

I 100% think CBT without these supports, especially for people w/ ADHD, can be unhelpful or even damaging, so I hate seeing stories on Twitter of people getting fobbed off with "have u tried CBT" by their GPs.

I was fortunate to get free access to CBT from a professional who managed all aspects of my treatment from therapy to medication, and that is what I think made CBT a success for me. 

I still use aspects of it to manage anxiety, though happy to say it's no longer disordered.
3. I did CBT alongside with medication that worked two stop the rumination I would do endlessly, for just long enough to step outside of my own head and complete the CBT exercises.

2. I did CBT to address specific issues I had with severe anxiety at the time. It was never sold to me as a cure-all, just enough to get me out of my house and taking the steps I needed to do that would eventually lift me out of the depression I was in.

1. I did CBT during sessions with a skilled psychiatrist once a week for about 6 months. Doing the CBT exercises on my own outside the sessions was (and still is) very difficult for many ADHD-related reasons.

I've noticed some backlash against Cognitive Behavioural Therapy for ADHD lately, and I wanted to add my two cents.

CBT worked well for me to address some acute anxiety issues about 10 years ago (that I now know were caused by untreated ADHD). 

Reasons why I think it worked:
@danidonovan This probably isn't possible, but getting a dog made my parents' indoor cat sooo much more active. She loves to stalk him, and they play together a lot!

@purrcarriepurrr Also, as an ADHDer who runs a business, money allows me to hire people who are can pick up some of the things I have to do for my business that ADHD makes difficult. That's not available for most, they're just expected to struggle through the parts of their jobs that are hard.
@purrcarriepurrr Definitely it does. I've been fortunate enough to be able to pay for quite a bit of support that's helped me in more than I can count since being diagnosed with ADHD a year ago.

@HealthyADHD Took an ADHD course where they called this the "Green Zone", when you're feeling really good and energized (vs. Yellow or Red).

With ADHD, when we're in the green zone we need to remind ourselves that it's not a permanent state of being, to hold back a bit to avoid burning out.

@scatterkeir @jamesgent101 That is definitely a trap I fall into as well. 

I think because while I'm actually doing the task, I enjoy pinging from task to task and multitasking MORE than doing one thing at a time, I'm drawn to it, but it doesn't allow me to be productive enough, so have to stop myself.

@jamesgent101 @scatterkeir That's definitely me too, but for me what I call "pinging" is this this super specific form of not focusing that I do where I literally just ping, ping, ping every like 30 seconds, and it's really hard to stop once I get into it, as opposed to my baseline level of lack of focus

By pinging, I mean that thing where you start one thing, then realise you have to do another thing so start the other thing, and so on, and so on, just spending all your time and energy task switching and not on the tasks themselves.

I've just realised that often when I start "pinging" about from task to task, not managing to make any meaningful headway on anything, it's because I've schedule too much for myself to do within a set period of time.

Possible ADHD time blindness hack?

ADHD + perfectionism:

1. Feel shame/regret about something you haven’t accomplished yet that you would like to

2. Impulsively overcommit yourself to doing or achieving that thing or goal 

3. Failing to achieve it because impulse is not a great long term motivator 

4. Repeat

#askADHD Are you avoidant of thinking about your emotions? 

For me, I find it very hard to just sit and feel certain emotions because my brain almost automatically jumps away to a million other thoughts.
You can suck at the simple things because of your ADHD and still be amazing at super complicated, difficult life stuff. It's not a linear scale of abilities.

This is your regular reminder if you're like me and beat yourself up for struggling with "simple" stuff like showering or sleeping, those are actually the things ADHD makes difficult.

You inability to do laundry regularly does not mean you suck at EVERYTHING else in life.
